newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: UN arms inspectors ground flights in Iraq.
newsitem.headline: UN arms inspectors ground flights in Iraq.

text.p: U.N. weapons inspectors have grounded their surveillance helicopters in iraq because of the confrontation between Baghdad and the United States, thereby putting on hold some of their sensitive work.

Rolf Ekeus, head of the U.N. Special Commission in charge of ridding Iraq of weapons of mass destruction, told a news conference: "We have grounded all air operaltions for the time being. Our people are still in Baghdad but we can't carry out sensitive operations...becasue of the (current situation.).
Ekeus said that the new no-flight zone imposed by the United States shortly after it unleashed cruise missiles against targets in southern Iraq, now reached the outskirts of Baghdad.
"We have two sides which are facing each other. We are aware these are no ordinary times so I don't want them to fly," he said.
He said he had about 104 inspectors and support staff in Baghdad and all had been told to stay in radio contract in case of emergencies.
The lack of helicopters, he said, would hinder his inspections of sites where Iraq might still be hiding weapons because of the lack of air surveillance to spot any movement.
"The search for sensitive items must be kept on hold," he said, repeating that "We suspect that Iraq is having an active policy of concealment of these prohibited items."
